bestBHT.bht: Always belonging to 'I thank my God', I thank Him because I hear about your love and faith towards the Lord Jesus. It is necessary for me to mention this when I call you to mind and make mention of you always in my prayers. I don't cease to give thanks for you, whether I am present or absent, because it is vital to remember and pray for both congregations and individual members. I thank my God for the grace bestowed upon you, Philemon, and I continuously lift up prayers of thanksgiving and intercession for you.

Henry Alford: always belongs to 'I thank my God'... The first participle, making mention, expands 'I thank'."
the second, hearing, gives the ground of the thank—for that I hear."
thy love—to the saints: the faith—toward the Lord Jesus. The order is inverted: but it is necessary for perspicuity thus to distribute.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: — joined by Alford with, “I thank my God.”
Albert Barnes: I thank my God - That is, for what I hear of you.
Making mention of thee always in my prayers
To remember with affectionate concern these churches and individuals, as he did, Paul must have been a man of much prayer.
Marvin Vincent: The phrases express the two ideas, mentioning thee when I call thee to mind. In my prayers.
The clauses are arranged crosswise, love referring to saints, faith to Christ.
John Calvin: It deserves attention, that he at the same time prays for that very thing for which he 'gives thanks.'
Even the most perfect, so long as they live in the world, never have so good ground for congratulation as not to need prayers.
God may grant to them, not only to persevere till the end, but likewise to make progress from day to day.
Philip Schaff: I thank my God. He has just spoken of God as the giver of Christian grace, and the memory of such grace working in Philemon’s life, calls forth his instant thanksgiving.
always... 'I cease not to give thanks for you.'

Whether present or absent, the apostle laid not aside his ‘care of all the churches.’ And here we can note that his heart was full not only of thought for congregations, but for individual members wherever their state was known to him.
Archibald T. Robertson: Always (παντοτε). Goes with ευχαριστω though so far away in the Greek sentence.
Making mention of thee (μνειαν σου ποιουμενος). See 1 Thessalonians 1:2 for this phrase.
John Gill: I thank my God,.... Meaning on account, of Philemon, for the grace bestowed upon him, thereafter mentioned."
The apostle was a man much in prayer, frequent at the throne of grace; and he prayed not for himself only, but for all the saints, for all the churches and ministers of the Gospel."
He remembered them, and put up petitions, with thanksgivings, for them; and so he did for Philemon.

bhtAttempts.bht: I always thank my God because I hear about your love and faith towards the Lord Jesus. It is necessary for me to mention this when I call you to mind in my prayers. I don't cease to give thanks for you, whether I am present or absent, because my heart is full of thought and care for both congregations and individual members. It is important to note that I also pray for the very thing that I give thanks for, as even the most perfect need prayers and the progress of God's grace in their lives. I thank my God for the grace bestowed upon you, Philemon, and I continuously lift up prayers of thanksgiving and intercession for you.
